awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Legged Locomotion Across Scales: Closing the Loop Between Task Planning and Motion Control
awd_abstract_narration: This award seeks to introduce tightly integrated locomotion control and motion planning strategies for agile, highly-mobile legged robots with radically different sizes and morphologies. To realize the potential of these machines in real-world applications, basic movements must be composed to synthesize more complex locomotion behaviors that achieve desirable high-level planning objectives. As dynamic legged robots are becoming increasingly more capable, the need for hierarchically consistent locomotion planning strategies that translate descending task-level commands to suitable low-level control actions that harness the platform's locomotion capabilities becomes pressing. To address this need, this effort pursues new directions (i) in dynamic legged locomotion, by offering a portable library of locomotion primitives; (ii) in robot control, by providing constructive feedback reduction strategies and stochastic data-driven methods that map complex legged robot platforms to behavior-encoding target models; and (iii) in hybrid systems, by introducing a framework for complexity reduction through multiple layers of information processing and control action. This research effort seeks to enable legged machines to perform real-world tasks reliably and efficiently. This way, it promotes many different applications, including industrial, agricultural, and emergency response applications that require highly mobile and versatile robots.  This effort also includes substantial educational and community outreach components, aiming at attracting underrepresented groups to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. In addition, by pairing high-school teachers with graduate students, this effort addresses the critical need for K-12 teachers to stay current and articulate their teaching with the demands of college courses.

Objectives and Motivation:

Over the past few years, there has been an explosion of robots inspired by the way animals move. Undoubtedly, reproducing features of animal locomotion on machines is a fascinating area of research. Yet, to realize the potential of such machines in real-world applications, movements must be coordinated and regulated to synthesize more complex behaviors that achieve desirable task-level objectives. As dynamic animal-inspired robots are becoming increasingly more capable, the need for hierarchically consistent locomotion control and motion planning strategies that translate descending task-level commands to suitable low-level control actions that harness the platform's locomotion capabilities becomes pressing. This project responded to this need by introducing a framework within which dynamic locomotion control and motion planning strategies can be seamlessly integrated. We used legged robots as a paradigm for addressing the interdependencies in the functional organization of hierarchically structured locomotion control and planning policies. Robots in this family - from small hexapeds with masses on the order of grams, to large bipeds and quadrupeds weighting tens of kilos, and from slow-moving crawlers to rapid runners to reliable climbers - exhibit a wide range of locomotion behaviors that can be composed to synthesize more complex ones that meet desired objectives. Beyond legged robots, the collection of methods introduced in this project is expected to lead to a deeper understanding of robots, which - like legged robots - move through their environment via intermittent, cyclic, forceful interactions.

 

Intellectual Merit:

This project addressed fundamental challenges associated with planning the motion of dynamically dexterous legged robots across different scales. To achieve this goal, our research introduced a collection of mathematical models, analysis techniques, and feedback control synthesis methods, pushing the envelope (i) in dynamic locomotion, by offering portable libraries of locomotion primitives; (ii) in robot control, by providing constructive feedback reduction strategies and stochastic data-driven methods that map complex plants to behavior-encoding target models; and, (iii) in hybrid systems, by introducing a framework for complexity reduction through multiple layers of information processing and control action. At the core of our approach is the formulation of nature-inspired reductive models that distill locomotion principles shared across different platforms, thus offering unifying, platform-independent, descriptions of task-level behavior. These reductive models effectively constitute the link between the platform's low-level implementation specifics and the planner's high-level mission objectives.

Our approach relies on composing (nominally) periodic, dynamically-stable gaits representing primitive locomotion behaviors to generate more complex motions that can address the challenges associated with moving in natural environments in a provably safe manner. Quantifying safety for such systems is challenging: composing gait primitives effectively causes the system to be in a ``perpetual'' transient phase, never converging to any of the underlying primitives. The resulting evolution can be highly irregular. We have addressed this challenge by introducing a novel approach to ensure safe operation, effectively redefining safety for dynamic locomotion. We have applied our methods in a variety of robotic applications that require reactive planning in the presence of widely varying uncertainty.

Furthermore, in our multi-scale approach to artificial legged locomotion, we have introduced probabilistic techniques for modeling miniature legged robots. As size decreases, stringent weight specifications and constraints on power density prohibit extensive reliance on actuators and sensors. Compounding the challenge, the uncertainty dominating the motion of robots at small scales call for systematic model validation and parameter estimation methods for locomotion behavioral models. This project developed such methods, effectively providing tractable means for quantifying the extent at which a model - i.e., a mathematical idealization - captures the true behavior of a robot in a probabilistic fashion. Our approach is data driven, and it uses robot data to extend deterministic models of locomotion behavior to stochastic ones, offering probabilistic guarantees for the capability of the model to capture the experimental data.

 

Broader Impact:

This research introduced systematic methods for hierarchically organized and tightly integrated locomotion control and motion planning algorithms for dynamic legged robots, enabling these machines to perform real-world tasks reliably and efficiently. This way, our effort promotes the advancement of a host of real-life applications, including industrial, agricultural, and emergency response applications that require highly mobile and versatile robot platforms. By developing portable algorithms for legged robots, this work will result in cost and time savings for researchers, developers, educators, and end-users in robotics. The project included substantial educational and community outreach components, and provided numerous opportunities for training University students at both the graduate and undergraduate levels.
